title: Swimming Injury and Diagnosis
content: In the summer of 2009, during training for a marathon swim, the right shoulder started hurting during any training swim that exceeded six hours. By late July, the pain was getting very sharp by hour four of each training swim. After an arthrogram (an MRI where they inject contrast directly into the shoulder joint) and a visit with an orthopedic surgeon, a torn labrum was diagnosed. The surgeon recommended surgery, which would require being in a sling for six weeks post-op and a period of no swimming for nine months.

title: Continued Training Despite Injury
content: Despite the pain, the decision was made to continue training. However, the decision was made to opt out of a very tough swim in favor of a more manageable one. The swim turned out to be extremely painful, with the last eight hours spent screaming under the water from the pain.

title: Post-Swim Condition and Decision Against Surgery
content: A week following the swim, another arthrogram showed the tear was more or less the same. The decision was made to forgo surgery due to the unappealing thought of not swimming for 9 months. Instead, a break was taken from marathon swimming and focus was shifted to Master’s swimming and racing in the pool.

title: Weakening Shoulder and Decision for Surgery
content: By 2012, the right shoulder was getting weaker and weaker, even with limited swimming to one hour per day. By late 2013, the shoulder was so weak that bench pressing an unloaded bar or doing even one pushup caused terrible pain. Surgery was scheduled for early 2014.

title: Alternative Treatment and Recovery
content: Before the surgery, a physical therapist hypothesized that the tear was not the cause of the pain and complete loss of strength. Instead, the deltoid, triceps, and subscapularis were blamed. The decision was made to delay surgery for six months to give the therapist a chance to work on the fix. Within six months, the shoulder was back to about 80% of previous function and today it’s at 95% which implies no functional limitation and no pain.

title: Importance of Proper Exercise and Warm Up
content: As we age, we need to increase our ratio of proper tissue warm up and range of motion practice, relative to actual intense exercise. Tissue becomes less elastic, and motor units lose their signals, so if we don’t use it we lose it. This is true of athletes, and normal civilians.

title: Exercise Videos for Neck, Upper Back, and Shoulders
content: A sequence of movements and exercises designed to get your neck, upper back, and shoulders ready to do anything, free of pain, have been put together. The sequence includes soft tissue preparation, dynamic stabilization, and loaded exercises. There are also exercises specifically for the rotator cuff and to improve scapular health.
